I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  Education indicators for Pakistan are grim, with a low adult literacy rate, low expected 
years of schooling, and considerable challenges in terms of access and quality of learning.1 
Educational challenges in Sindh are more acute than in Pakistan generally. They include limited 
access  to  education,  poor  quality  education,  and  weak  education  sector  governance  and 
management. The performance of the education sector is weak in Sindh, especially at the 
secondary education level. Access to education is low and there are wide disparities across 
gender, geography, and socio-economic quintiles. The quality of education in Sindh is poor and 
learning levels are low across all subjects, and particularly for mathematics and science. This is 
due to several factors, including the poor quality of the teaching force, an outdated secondary 
examination system and weak sector governance and management. 
 
2.  The proposed Sindh Secondary Education Improvement Project (SSEIP) will support the 
Sindh School Education and Literacy Department (SSELD) to implement aspects of the Sindh 
Education Sector Plan (SESP) 2014–2018 by increasing access to, and improving the quality of, 
secondary education in the province. Project outputs are: (i) network of quality secondary schools 
expanded; (ii) teacher, quality, management and accountability enhanced; and (iii) secondary 
education sector governance strengthened. The project is estimated to cost $165 million, of which 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will finance $150 million from ordinary capital resources 
($40.5 million concessional). The Government of Sindh (the Government) will contribute in-kind 
assistance of $15 million. The project will be implemented from 2019 to 2024. The project is 
included in the draft Pakistan country operations business plan 2018–2020 as a firm 2018 project.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
3.  The  transaction  technical  assistance  (TRTA)  is  justified  given  the  scope  of  project 
activities and the specialist nature of skills required in areas such as the design of PPPs, teacher 
training and accountability, and examination reform. The TRTA will provide technical inputs and 
assessments to assist the Government and ADB to develop a project that is aligned with the 
Pakistan country partnership strategy 2015–2019 and the SESP 2014–2018.   
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
4.  The TRTA has three outputs:  
 
•  Output 1. Detailed project design developed and costed. This output will develop the 
technical design parameters and detailed costings for the three project outputs, including: 
(i) design of the project, including PPP programs, teacher training and accountability, and 
examination reform; (ii) preparation of detailed project costings, including civil works, 
consultancy, capacity building and project implementation; (iii) preparation of project 
design and monitoring framework, including specification of performance indicators and 
project activities; (iv) identification of capacity building for the Sindh Education Foundation 
(SEF) and the PPP node in SSELD; (v) review and updating (as required) architectural 
designs for project schools; (vi) identification of sites for project schools; (vii) development 
of the project procurement plan; and (viii) specification of project implementation plan.

•  Output 2. Project due diligence undertaken. This output will support  project due 
diligence, including: (i) education sector assessment, (ii) environmental assessment, (iii) 
economic and financial analysis, (iv) gender, poverty and social analysis, (v) financial 
management assessment of the executing and implementing agencies, (vi) procurement 
capacity  assessment  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies;  and  (vii)  risk 
assessment and management plan.  
 
•  Output 3. Project processing and implementation startup facilitated. This will include 
(i) assisting in the preparation of all documents required for project processing, including 
the Report and Recommendation of the President (RRP), all RRP linked documents, and 
the project administration manual; and (ii) project startup and implementation support.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
5.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $1.1 million equivalent, of which $1.0 million will be financed 
from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-6).  Government  will  provide  in-kind 
assistance of $0.1 million in the form of taxes, office accommodation, and counterpart staff. The 
cost estimates and financing plan are listed in Appendix 1. The Government was informed that 
approval of the TRTA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
6.  ADB will administer the TRTA. The SSELD will be the executing agency. The Social Sector 
Division of the Central and West Asia Department will coordinate project preparation with the 
SSELD reform support unit, the SEF, and the Project Management and Implementation Unit of 
USAID’s Sindh Basic Education Program. The TRTA will be implemented from November 2017 
to December 2019 to ensure effective project preparation and startup. Implementation will be 
coordinated with other development partners. Disbursements will be made in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). 
Implementation arrangements are in Table 1.

7.  Consulting services. ADB will recruit individual consultants to implement the TRTA. 
Consultant requirements are estimated at 18.5 person-months of international inputs and 29 
person-months of national inputs. Additional technical consultants and resource persons may be 
recruited in areas such as teacher training and accountability, PPPs, examination reform, gender, 
safeguards, and as well as in areas such as school design and procurement. The project may 
also recruit a firm to conduct an analysis of, and identify suitable sites for, schools to be 
constructed under the project. This will involve several key tasks, including (i) identifying school 
sites to ensure that the project maximizes its impact on target groups such as girls and rural 
populations;  and  (ii)  assessing  the  suitability  of  sites  for  construction  of  project  schools. 
Consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and the associated project administration instructions/technical assistance staff 
instructions.

TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
International Consultants 
 
1.  Education economist and team leader (6 person-months). The education economist 
and team leader should have a doctorate in economics from a recognized university and at least 
15 years’ international experience in leading preparation of education sector programs and 
projects. The specialist should also have experience in secondary education analysis and reform 
in a Pakistani context, including dialogue on education policy, program reform and implementation, 
and institutional aspects. Key tasks include: (i) advising on all aspects of the project and the 
associated TRTA; (ii) overseeing the development of a project design that is aimed at improving 
access to, and the quality of, the Sindh secondary education system; (iii) updating the education 
sector assessment; (iv) undertaking the economic analysis for the project; (v) in collaboration with 
the financial management specialist, preparing the financial analysis for the project including 
proposing strategies to ensure its financial sustainability; (vi) reviewing ADB and other funding 
agencies’ past, ongoing, and planned assistance to school education and drawing lessons for 
preparing a feasible project design and implementation arrangements; (vii) providing advice on 
the design of education PPP programs; and (viii) provide advice on project startup. As team leader, 
the consultant’s key tasks include: (i) coordinating the work of the consulting team; (ii) liaising with 
the implementing agencies and other government stakeholders; (iii) overseeing the preparation 
of all project and TRTA documentation.  
 
2.  Education facilities specialist (2 person-months). The school building design specialist 
should have at least a Master’s degree in architecture, engineering or equivalent, with a minimum 
of 10 years’ international experience in designing schools and other educational facilities. The 
specialist should have excellent knowledge of school design principles, specifications, as well as 
relevant building, safety and seismic requirements. Key tasks include: (i) providing technical 
advice on school building design and construction and for the addition of basic facilities to public 
schools such as toilets, boundary walls and laboratories; (ii) reviewing or updating/preparing 
architectural designs for the construction, renovation and expansion of school buildings and other 
facilities such as toilets, boundary walls, and laboratories; (iii) preparing, in combination with the 
project procurement specialists, bid documents, bills of quantities and cost estimates for the 
construction of school buildings and facilities in line with approved specifications; (iv) coordinating, 
with  project  management  unit  staff,  the  process  for  identifying  sites  suitable  for  school 
construction or upgrading; and (v) developing an implementation plan for construction, renovation 
and upgrading of schools and other facilities. The specialist will also  provide inputs to all 
documents required for loan processing. 
 
3.  Public  finance  and  governance  specialist  (1.5  person-months).  The  financial 
management specialist should have a qualification in accounting, management or finance, a 
recognized professional accountancy qualification, and at least 15 years’ relevant experience. 
The specialist should have extensive experience conducting financial management assessments 
for international financial institutions, including ADB. The specialist’s tasks include: (i) undertaking 
a financial management assessment of the executing agency, including through an assessment 
of previous financial management assessments; (ii) assessing the capacity of the executing 
agency for planning and budgeting, management and financial accounting, reporting, auditing, 
internal controls, and information systems (iii) reviewing proposed disbursement and funds-flow 
arrangements; (v) determining a financial management risk rating and identifying measures to 
address identified deficiencies; and (vi) assessing and reaching agreement on financial reporting, 
auditing and public disclosure arrangements for the project, and, as appropriate, identifying and

7 
agreeing arrangements for receiving financial statements from the executing agency and IAs. The 
specialist will also provide inputs to all documents required for loan processing . 
 
4.  Finance and costing specialist (3 person-months). The finance and costing specialist 
should have at least an advanced degree in economics, finance or related discipline, and at least 
10 years’ experience in designing or implementing projects in the education sector in developing 
countries. Experience in Asia and on ADB projects would be an asset. The specialist should have 
advanced knowledge of Excel. The specialist will (i) assess financial issues related to the project; 
(ii) prepare, in coordination with other specialists, cost estimates for the proposed project (with 
detailed cost tables for all components and activities) and a financing plan; and (iii) analyze the 
fiscal framework and financial procedures and recommend strategies to ensure sustainability and 
accountability of the proposed project. The specialist will also provide inputs to all documents 
required for loan processing . 
 
5.  Procurement  and  project  startup  specialist  (6  person-months).  The  procurement 
specialist  should  have  at  least  a  Bachelor’s  degree  in  logistics,  engineering,  business 
administration or related field, with at least 10 years’ experience in the education sector. The 
specialist should have experience in undertaking procurement capacity assessments, developing 
procurement plans and preparing bidding documents for international financial institutions, and 
preferably for ADB. The specialist’s tasks will include, but not be limited to, the following: (i) 
preparing the procurement plan and procurement capacity assessment of the executing agency 
and IAs, in accordance with ADB Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time); 
(ii) helping the executing agency prepare a plan of procurement activities covering the project 
implementation period; (iii) undertaking a capacity assessment of the executing agency and IAs; 
(iv) identifying procurement constraints and challenges in rural areas of Sindh and mechanisms 
for addressing these; (v) collecting data, including market prices, required to determine the cost 
of constructing, outfitting and equipping schools, to assist in preparing project cost tables; (vi) 
developing a realistic schedule and cost estimates for the design, supervision, inspection, and 
maintenance of proposed procurement activities; (vii) preparing master bidding documents for all 
procurement (in combination with the school building specialist for civil works); (viii) organizing 
procurement capacity development workshops for the executing agency and IAs of the ensuing 
project; and (ix) providing project startup assistance, including assisting in the strengthening of 
the IAs; modifying and updating the project procurement plan, project implementation plan, and 
project costings; assisting in the preparation of terms of reference and bidding documents; and 
assisting in other project start-up, monitoring and related tasks, as required.  The specialist will 
also provide inputs to all documents required for loan processing . 
 
National Consultants 
 
6.  Data analysis and monitoring and evaluation specialist and coordinator (6 person-
months).  The data analysis and monitoring and evaluation specialist should have at least a 
Bachelor’s degree in economics or related discipline. The specialist should have at least 5 years’ 
experience in data analysis, and a strong record of analysis of the Pakistani education sector. 
Recent  experience  as  a  consultant  with  international  financial  institutions  is  required.  The 
specialist’s tasks will include: (i) gathering and analyzing data; (ii) developing a monitoring and 
evaluation  system  for  the  SSEIP;  (iii)  liaising  closely  with  the  executing  agency  and  IAs, 
development partners and sector stakeholders in the preparation and startup of the project; (iv) 
providing inputs into the work of other members of the project preparation team; (v) reviewing ADB 
and other funding agencies’ past, ongoing, and planned assistance to school education and 
drawing lessons for preparing a feasible project design and implementation arrangements; (vi) 
assisting in the review of ADB and other funding agencies’ past, ongoing, and planned assistance

to  school  education  and  drawing  lessons  for  preparing  a  feasible  project  design  and 
implementation arrangements; and (vii) assist in project startup. The specialist will also support 
the team leader and assist in coordinating the project preparation and startup work. The specialist 
will also provide inputs to all documents required for loan processing. 
 
7.  Education facilities specialist (3 person-months). The school building design specialist 
should have at least a Bachelor’s degree in architecture, engineering or equivalent, with a 
minimum of 10 years’ experience in designing schools and other educational facilities in Pakistan. 
The specialist should have excellent knowledge of school design specifications and relevant 
building, safety and seismic codes. The specialist’s tasks include: (i) serving as a technical expert 
in relation to the project for school building design and construction and for the addition of basic 
facilities to public schools such as toilets, boundary walls and laboratories; (ii) reviewing or 
updating/preparing architectural designs for the construction, renovation and expansion of school 
buildings and other facilities such as toilets, boundary walls, and laboratories; (iii) preparing, in 
combination with the project procurement specialists, bid documents, bills of quantities and cost 
estimates for the construction of school buildings and facilities in line with approved specifications; 
(iv) coordinating, with project management unit staff, the process for identifying sites suitable for 
school construction or upgrading. The specialist will also provide inputs to all documents required 
for loan processing. 
 
8.  Procurement  and  project  startup  specialist  (6  person-months).  The  procurement 
specialist  should  have  at  least  a  Bachelor’s  degree  in  logistics,  engineering,  business 
administration or related field, with at least 10 years’ experience in the education sector in 
Pakistan.  The  specialist  should  have  experience  in  undertaking  procurement  capacity 
assessments, developing procurement plans and preparing bidding documents for international 
financial  institutions,  and  preferably  for  ADB.  The  specialist’s  tasks  will  be  to  assist  the 
international procurement specialist in: (i) preparing the procurement plan and procurement 
capacity assessment of the executing agency, in accordance with ADB Procurement Guidelines 
(2013, as amended from time to time); (ii) helping the executing agency prepare a plan of 
procurement activities covering the whole of the project implementation period; (iii) undertaking a 
capacity assessment of the executing agency and IAs; (iv) identifying procurement constraints 
and challenges in rural areas of Sindh and mechanisms for addressing these; (v) collecting data, 
including market prices, required to determine the cost of constructing, outfitting and equipping 
schools, to assist in preparing project cost tables; (v)i preparing master bidding documents for all 
procurement (in combination with the school building specialist for civil works); (vii) advising on 
any procurement issues that may arise; and (vii) providing training and other required support to 
address procurement capacity gaps in the executing agency or IAs; and (vii) providing project 
startup assistance, including assisting in the strengthening of the IAs; modifying and updating the 
project procurement plan, project implementation plan, and project costings; assisting in the 
preparation of terms of reference and bidding documents; and assisting in other project start-up, 
monitoring and related tasks, as required. The specialist will also provide inputs to all documents 
required for loan processing. 
 
9.  Teacher  professional  development  specialist  (3  person-months).  The  teacher 
professional development specialist should have at least a Master’s degree in education or related 
discipline, as well as substantial experience in the analysis and reform of teacher professional 
development in Pakistan. Key tasks include: (i) documenting and assessing the current pre-
service and in-service teacher training system, strategies and proposed reforms in Sindh including 
the new continuous professional development (CPD) framework; (ii) identifying strengths and 
weaknesses and potential areas for improvement of the current professional development system 
in Sindh and (iii) preparing a plan for implementing improved pre-service training and in-service

9 
training/CPD for teachers including stronger classroom support. The specialist will also provide 
inputs to all documents required for loan processing.  
 
10.  Student  assessment  and  examination  specialist  (3  person-months).  The  student 
assessment and examination specialist should have at least a Master’s degree in education or 
related  discipline,  as  well  as  substantial  experience  in  the  analysis  and  reform  of  student 
assessment and examinations, including knowledge and/or experience of the current situation in 
Sindh. Key tasks include: (i) documenting and assessing the secondary education student 
assessment  and  examination  system,  strategies  and  proposed  reforms  in  Sindh;  and  (ii) 
identifying strengths and weaknesses and potential areas for improvement of the current of the 
student assessment and examination system in Sindh. The specialist will also provide inputs to 
all documents required for loan processing. 
 
11.  Environmental  safeguards  specialist  (2  person-months).  The  environmental 
safeguards specialist should have at least a Master’s degree in environmental engineering or 
environmental management and extensive experience in conducting environmental assessments. 
Key tasks include: (i) examining the environmental implications of civil works planned under the 
SSEIP; (ii) carrying out a diagnostic assessment of applicable and relevant laws, regulations, 
rules, and procedures for managing and mitigating the environmental impact of the project; and 
(iii) prepare an initial environmental examination report. The assessment will include an evaluation 
of the SSEIP’s arrangements for (i) early screening and mitigation of environmental impacts, (ii) 
information  disclosure mechanisms  and consultations  with stakeholders,  and (iii) grievance 
redress procedures. The specialist will also provide inputs to all documents required for loan 
processing. 
 
12.  Gender and social safeguards specialist (4 person-months). The gender and social 
safeguards specialist should have at least a Master’s degree in gender studies, social sciences, 
sociology or related discipline and at least 10 years’ experience in gender and social analysis and 
operations, including for ADB or other international financial institutions. The specialist should 
have expertise in conducting gender, poverty and social analysis and assessments in Pakistan, 
and expertise in the use of participatory methodologies to collect and analyze information, as well 
as a good understanding of ADB policies and requirements. Key tasks include: (i) preparing 
poverty, social and gender analyses in Sindh, including disaggregated analysis of the gender and 
social impacts and benefits of the project; (ii) identifying priority interventions and procedures to 
promote participation by, and benefits, to the poor, girls and women, and other disadvantaged 
groups under the project; (iii) preparing the GAP and the summary poverty reduction and social 
strategy; (iv) conducting consultations to help in identifying possible sites for school placement 
under the project; and (v) ensuring that all project outputs, including civil works, are gender 
inclusive. The specialist will also provide inputs to all documents required for loan processing. 
 
13.  Resettlement specialist (2 person-months). The resettlement specialist should have at 
least a Master’s degree in social sciences, sociology or related discipline and at least 10 years’ 
experience in social safeguards assessments, for ADB or other international financial institutions. 
The specialist should have expertise in conducting resettlement analysis in Pakistan and in the 
use  of  participatory  methodologies  to  collect  and  analyze  information,  as  well  as  a  good 
understanding of ADB policies and requirements. Key tasks include: (i) screening possible school 
sites  to  minimize  or  eliminate  the  need  for  involuntary  resettlement  as  defined  in  ADB’s 
Involuntary Resettlement Policy and OMF2 on involuntary resettlement; and (ii) developing a 
resettlement plan in accordance with ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy and OMF2 if any of 
the sites for rehabilitation or expansion will result in involuntary resettlement. The specialist will 
also provide inputs to all documents required for loan processing.
